title: 109_hr2204
content: The "527 Transparency Act of 2005" requires mandatory monthly reporting. The "527 Transparency Act of 2005" mandates political organizations to file monthly reports with the Secretary for any contributions or expenditures related to exempt functions. Reports are due by the 20th day after the end of each month, except during election years when pre-election reports are required. The amendment requires political organizations to file three reports: a pre-election report due 15 days before an election, a post-general election report due 30 days after the election, and a year-end report due by January 31 of the following year. The amendment is effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2005. SEC. 4956 imposes an excise tax on managers of 527 organizations that fail to comply with disclosure requirements. Tax is imposed on a political organization for failing to meet disclosure requirements regarding contributions or expenditures, with the tax amount being 30 percent of the total. The organization is liable for the tax, but organization managers are jointly and severally liable as well. Tax is imposed on a political organization for failing to meet disclosure requirements, with the tax amount being 30 percent of the total. Organization managers are also liable for the tax. Tax is imposed on political organizations for failing to meet disclosure requirements, with the tax amount set at 30 percent. The organization managers are also held liable for this tax. Additionally, amendments made by this subsection will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2005, and there is a denial of the gift tax exclusion for transfers to political organizations. The text discusses exceptions to the transfer of money or property to political organizations for tax purposes. It mentions that transfers may not be subject to tax if the organization fails to disclose required information. Additionally, contributors must be notified if the gift tax exception is denied due to lack of disclosure. The Secretary determines failure to disclose by an organization, it must notify contributors within 90 days. The exception under section 2501(a)(4)(A) does not apply to contributions in that calendar year. Effective date is after December 31, 2005. SEC. 4. SIMULTANEOUS TRANSMISSION OF REPORTS TO FEDERAL ELECTION COMMISSION. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require political organizations under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to file reports with both the Secretary of the Treasury and the Federal Election Commission simultaneously. The copy filed with the Treasury shall be treated as a report filed with the Commission. The amendment made by subsection (a) shall take effect on January 1, 2006.
